Award.AwardTitle: Probing the Effects of Highly Bent and Twisted DNA on Transcription by RNA Polymerase

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cells contain a large number of genes that are expressed in complex patterns to ensure proper cellular function and differentiation. It is well established that regulatory proteins play a central role in transcriptional control and regulate the activity of RNA polymerases (RNAP). In addition, various lines of evidence related to supercoiling, looped DNA topologies, and chromatin remodeling suggest that RNAP activity may also be regulated via the nano-mechanical properties of DNA. We hypothesize that bending and twisting of the DNA template directly regulate the activity of RNAPs. To test this hypothesis we will generate DNA minicircles of a length of about 100 base pairs to introduce bending strain energy and torsion into DNA templates of a physiologically relevant magnitude in the absence of repressors or any other regulatory proteins. Using these minicircle DNA templates and molecular beacon-based transcription assays to directly detect synthesized mRNA, we will characterize changes in the kinetic properties of T7-RNAP. We will also develop assays to track the transcription from single DNA minicircles and to directly modulate torsion in DNA molecules while recording the activity of RNAP. Lastly, we will utilize computational rod models to predict the relationship between DNA topology and transcription.

Our research on the role of DNA template mechanics on the activity of RNA polymerases has broader implications for the biological, medical and physical sciences. The work will close an important gap in our fundamental knowledge of the biology of DNA mechanics. The proposed assays will facilitate a detailed characterization of the effects that DNA template topologies and mechanics have on the activity of RNAPs. If successful, this research expands our understanding of transcriptional regulation and compels a paradigm shift in how we think about and approach genetic switches and gene regulation. Thus, the work has important implications for the medical sciences and will contribute to a rational understanding of cell regulation, cellular control and tissue engineering. The multidisciplinary approach and techniques developed here will also benefit the study of numerous other DNA-binding enzymes, other areas of gene regulation and the study of molecular motors and the cytoskeleton.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The function of biological cells and tissues, including during their development and responses in health and disease, is ultimately controlled by the cell's genes. Understanding when and how particular genes in cells are activated (transcribed) while others are silenced, or more broadly, how gene expression patterns in cells are established and controlled, is essential and, despite significant progress,  remains of one of the outstanding challenges in modern biology.  It  is now well established that regulatory proteins play a central role in transcriptional control and regulate the activity of RNA polymerases. In addition, there is also significant evidence that supercoiling, which results in looped DNA topologies, and chromatin remodeling control the activity and binding of DNA-binding proteins which in turn, we hypothesized, is based on the nano-mechanical properties of DNA. Within this larger conceptual framework, the specific goals for this project were to develop the required, novel instrumentation to advance the analysis of the mechanical properties of single DNA molecules and examine how the bending and torsion of DNA directly effects the transcription of DNA by RNA polymerase.

We experimentally examined the hypothesis that bending and twisting of the DNA template directly regulate the transcriptional activity of RNAPs by generating a range of DNA minicircles of a length of about 100 base pairs. The tight curvature of these minicircles introduces physiologically relevant bending strain energy and torsion into DNA templates and, using T7RNAP as model polymerase, our measurements show that the elongation velocity and processivity during transcription can be repressed by more than two orders of magnitude. Combing electron-microscopy and Brownian dynamics modeling, we were also able to provide novel insights into how mechanical bending strains DNA to form hyperflexible regions that facilitate the formation of tight loops. Moreover, we have investigate the role of mechanical strain in transcriptional initiation and conclude that repression of RNAP during initiation is determined not only by the mechanics of the DNA template, but the torque generated by the RNAP also contributes. Taken together, these observations significantly advance our understanding of the role of mechanical factors in transcriptional control.

To enable more advanced measurements of the mechanical properties of DNA and its binding proteins at the level of single molecule, we also developed an electro-magnetic tweezers setup with the capability to (1) independently control force and torque in single molecules experiments, (2) extend the bandwidth of the entire tweezers system below the sub-millihertz domain to enable force and torque-clamp experiments and (3) allow tracking of the rotational motion of biomolecules in space with three independent  optoelectronic sensors. We conducted careful measurements of the torsional stiffness of DNA with this setup and evaluated the worm-like chain model for DNA.

The broader impact of our research on the role of DNA template mechanics and the activity of RNA polymerases ranges from the biological sciences to medicine and physics. The work has made important contributions to narrowing the gap in our fundamental knowledge of DNA mechanics. In a few words, our findings strongly support the hypothesis that the mechanics of DNA templates and the mechanical interactions between polymerases and template molecules provide important additional clues for regulating transcription. In addition, the technical and methodological advances made through this project will broadly benefit multidisciplinary research, including work on DNA-binding enzymes, other areas of gene regulation and the study of molecular motors and the cytoskeleton.
